Ratings.comment: Very sweet old man who gave me a good foundation of what Epidemiology is.

This was honestly one of the easiest classes I've ever taken... i went to class the first 4 times and then never again lol. Theres 4 tests but they are all online and he posts his notes , easy group writing projects due every 2-3 weeks but my group split it up to make it easy, he is nice but just stands on a podium and yaps...hence me not going

I've had him for two epi classes, one online and this one in person.  In this blended grad-undergrad course, he let us be responsible for getting as much or as little out of class as we wanted,. There were no tests or exams, just weekly participation assignments and a final presentation. He clearly enjoys teaching and is good at it
Great professor! Online zoom class but he also posts his recordings. Quizzes and tests are very straight forward and if you pay attention on zoom, class is super easy.

his lectures were very repetitive and made little sense, i dont recommend if you need to actually learn the coursework, but he is okay if you just need a GE credit, three midterms and 3/4 quizzes and the final are the only things graded. the class is based off of 100 points and every point is 1% of your final grade, very weird guy overall

Dr. Harris was a kind man, however, it can be difficult to be engaged in his lectures. I almost never attended his class meetings on Zoom and I got a good grade. He only rounds up by half percentages, so I could not convince him to round a 92 to an A.
Literally never went to class and only watched the review lectures. Super easy class and super smart guy

Professor Harris was great! His lectures were very interesting. He only graded based off of tests and quizzes, so you have to do well on those to pass the class. As long as you pay attention in lectures, especially review lectures, you should do well.

Professor Harris is very nice and I found the class decently interesting just very repetitive. The review lectures prep you for quizzes and tests very well. Very organized in the online format and very little work to do. Just 5 quizzes and 2 tests are graded.

Watch the lectures and you will do fine on the tests. The glass is graded on 2 midterms, 5 quizzes, and a final so you need to do well on those but it's very attainable if you watch the lectures and his review lecture.
Just do the assignments and you'll be cool, they're not hard.

Harris was great! Very accessible and funny. You don't need a textbook and honestly don't need to go to class unless it's a review day. Tests determine grade, but they aren't impossible. Studying review slides and not going to class will get you an A- or A

Dr. Harris is a wonderful man with a lot of experience in epidemiology. He made it very easy to meet with him outside of class and his review sessions went over basically everything on the exam. Going to lectures isn't required or necessary, but it definitely helps with comprehension! It's an easy A if you study.
This class only included quizzes and tests for the grade which made it a bit difficult but he does care about students and tries to help as much as he can.

Dr Harris MD PHD is the BEST of the BEST! Clinical fellowships are awarded to students who HONOR the GOLDEN RULE, not whining complainers. Do not be short-sighted and point-fixated. Students with lower Grades get nomination for Clinical promotion fellowships. Whining students with higher grades can write themselves recommendation letters.

I started with over a 100% after the first exam, and ended with an A- because its only out of 100 points so every single question on the three tests matters heavily. You don't need to go to lecture because the powerpoints are online. There are a few online quizzes that should be automatic 100s.

Dr. Harris definitely cares about his students success. The quizzes were easy and online. But the tests could be tricky. Just make sure to know the material well and this class should be an easy A. The lectures could be boring, but that happens with any subject.

Prof. Harris's class is just all about lectures. He's a very chill man, maybe a little too chill. If you have no interest in Epidemiology, you will likely find this class super boring. Review his PowerPoints and you will do fine on your exams. Epidemiology isn't of my interest, so it's not really for me. He's a helpful man though.
review power points and you'll be fine. Boring lecture but great professor

You don't need to attend lectures or read the book. I am an epidemiology minor and even I found his lectures to be boring. Attend the review session and read over the review slides and you'll do well. He is very kind, but boring.

NEVER experienced stricter grading in my life. Basically need to copy word for word from the examples she posts or you do terribly. The discussion posts are terrible and got marked off points for not doing things when I clearly did. Don't take this course unless you absolutely have to. 3-4 homework assignments a week each w/ 20+ minute lectures.

Not the worst, but the discussion post are lowkey hell, along with the CHPP assignments, but other than that, pretty nice. She's pretty considerate of others time and pushes back due dates. Response to emails pretty quickly as well. I'd recommend taking this course online.

She is a really nice person but I don't enjoy this class. For me, there is a lot of work assigned to us. If this was my only class and I didn't have other time consuming things it wouldn't be bad, but I do. Every week, there is either 1 essay to do or group work. My mental health has plummeted SIGNIFICANTLY. 3 essays due this week. I give up.

I took Intro Public Health asynchronous with her and she was great! The class was simple and easy to do well in if you complete assignments. There were 2 short lectures, a short assignment, and a short quiz for each week. There was a project and paper. Autumn was SUPER accessible out of class and holds a ton of office hours! We love her!
Very sweet old man who gave me a good foundation of what Epidemiology is.

This was honestly one of the easiest classes I've ever taken... i went to class the first 4 times and then never again lol. Theres 4 tests but they are all online and he posts his notes , easy group writing projects due every 2-3 weeks but my group split it up to make it easy, he is nice but just stands on a podium and yaps...hence me not going

I've had him for two epi classes, one online and this one in person.  In this blended grad-undergrad course, he let us be responsible for getting as much or as little out of class as we wanted,. There were no tests or exams, just weekly participation assignments and a final presentation. He clearly enjoys teaching and is good at it
Great professor! Online zoom class but he also posts his recordings. Quizzes and tests are very straight forward and if you pay attention on zoom, class is super easy.

his lectures were very repetitive and made little sense, i dont recommend if you need to actually learn the coursework, but he is okay if you just need a GE credit, three midterms and 3/4 quizzes and the final are the only things graded. the class is based off of 100 points and every point is 1% of your final grade, very weird guy overall

Dr. Harris was a kind man, however, it can be difficult to be engaged in his lectures. I almost never attended his class meetings on Zoom and I got a good grade. He only rounds up by half percentages, so I could not convince him to round a 92 to an A.
Literally never went to class and only watched the review lectures. Super easy class and super smart guy

Professor Harris was great! His lectures were very interesting. He only graded based off of tests and quizzes, so you have to do well on those to pass the class. As long as you pay attention in lectures, especially review lectures, you should do well.

Professor Harris is very nice and I found the class decently interesting just very repetitive. The review lectures prep you for quizzes and tests very well. Very organized in the online format and very little work to do. Just 5 quizzes and 2 tests are graded.

Watch the lectures and you will do fine on the tests. The glass is graded on 2 midterms, 5 quizzes, and a final so you need to do well on those but it's very attainable if you watch the lectures and his review lecture.
Just do the assignments and you'll be cool, they're not hard.

Harris was great! Very accessible and funny. You don't need a textbook and honestly don't need to go to class unless it's a review day. Tests determine grade, but they aren't impossible. Studying review slides and not going to class will get you an A- or A

Dr. Harris is a wonderful man with a lot of experience in epidemiology. He made it very easy to meet with him outside of class and his review sessions went over basically everything on the exam. Going to lectures isn't required or necessary, but it definitely helps with comprehension! It's an easy A if you study.
This class only included quizzes and tests for the grade which made it a bit difficult but he does care about students and tries to help as much as he can.

Dr Harris MD PHD is the BEST of the BEST! Clinical fellowships are awarded to students who HONOR the GOLDEN RULE, not whining complainers. Do not be short-sighted and point-fixated. Students with lower Grades get nomination for Clinical promotion fellowships. Whining students with higher grades can write themselves recommendation letters.

I started with over a 100% after the first exam, and ended with an A- because its only out of 100 points so every single question on the three tests matters heavily. You don't need to go to lecture because the powerpoints are online. There are a few online quizzes that should be automatic 100s.

Dr. Harris definitely cares about his students success. The quizzes were easy and online. But the tests could be tricky. Just make sure to know the material well and this class should be an easy A. The lectures could be boring, but that happens with any subject.

Prof. Harris's class is just all about lectures. He's a very chill man, maybe a little too chill. If you have no interest in Epidemiology, you will likely find this class super boring. Review his PowerPoints and you will do fine on your exams. Epidemiology isn't of my interest, so it's not really for me. He's a helpful man though.
review power points and you'll be fine. Boring lecture but great professor

You don't need to attend lectures or read the book. I am an epidemiology minor and even I found his lectures to be boring. Attend the review session and read over the review slides and you'll do well. He is very kind, but boring.

He has very boring lectures, but some interesting topics. Some lectures are long while others lasted only 20 minutes. If you go to the review sessions he pretty much goes over everything on the exams, which aren't difficult if you study the review slides. There are only two midterms and a final so you have to be very careful.

Extremely boring lectures. He just reads from the slides so attendance isn't mandatory. The slides are very hard to look at. Not sure why, but he chooses to make his slides yellow text on a bright blue background. Sounds like a Michigan fan-probably added to why I didn't like him. There are no homeworks or quizzes, just the midterm and final.

Class wasn't extremely hard but also wasn't enjoyable at all. Lectures were very boring and he made no effort to make any material interesting. Read quickly through power points and was very bad at explaining things. Also, class only had two grades: the midterm and the final. If you aren't careful you won't do well.

Extremely easy to cheat but I didnt just to be clear. Has a huge steep grading curve. Test are multiple choice/matching - extremely important to study. attendance is not mandatory at all. Extra credit is given at random times!

Dr. Harris is very knowledgeable about the material and has a lot of interesting things to say in lecture. However, he just reads off the Powerpoints, so going to lecture sometimes is not necessary. Exams are super easy. Easy A

I attended class 6 times. The professor was awesome and did not seem to care. His tests were fair, but they are weighted heavily.He even gave us a significant amount of bonus at the end to help with grades. I didn't need it but it was still nice.
This professor rocks! He encourages students to explore topics they are interested in present it.  He will go above and beyond to help students too.  Definitely recommend this class!

Class was really interesting. He tends to talk really fast and assume you understand graphs so you need to really pay attention. 10 movies for the first 10 lectures, they are interesting. Lecture isnt necessary if you have the book. Really nice guy instructor overall
Dr. Harris is a VERY intelligent professor, because his knowledge is so innate.  He offers extensive pathogenesis education. Interesting!

It has been my good luck to have had Dr. Harris. Excellent instructor. Mentors students. Cares too much, & increases his work load because of  faculty slackers. For the rater being critical of Dr. Harris, look to your own deficiencies as a student, instead of blaming the faculty member.
Learned more from him than in any of my other classes.  He will ask you to think and not just spit stuff out at you.  Take good notes, too...does a great review for midterm and final exams.

Very early class twice a week. He makes the information as boring as possible, I've never fallen asleep during a class until this one. Tests are based completely on powerpoints, and he doesn't take attendence. So don't even go. Easy A, just review powerpoints.
The tough grading comes from the TA's in my experience not her, and compared to my other Gen Eds, the workload seemed similar. If u just do your work you will be fine and learn useful stuff.

Told us to ask and email questions when needed, but would give passive-aggressive responses or not respond at all. Her rude demeanor made many nervous to talk to her. So many assignments and she is not an easy grader. Constantly nagged about being prepared and professional, but couldn't even uphold her own standards herself half of the time.

Avoid her classes if possible. She knows her stuff but is not a good professor. She encourages students to ask questions then acts very annoyed and rude when people do ask her questions. She spends about 15 minutes at the beginning of every class yelling at us for emailing her and asking questions. Also way too much work for a GE.

nope!!! She knows her stuff and the quizzes, but her demeanor is bad! She encourages questions but then is annoyed when you DO ask. I went to her office hours and she was angry the second I asked my question. I did not feel comfortable asking her anything else. I as more comfortable emailing the TA about a grade than her. Way too much for a GE.

As a freshman, this class was overwhelming. We have an APA paper due at least one paper each week. Graders are PICKY, often taking points for stupid stuff. Much of the work felt tedious, and Dr. Aguolu marked attendance weekly, adding pressure since missing class could hurt our grades. Would only take this class if it's required for you.

Don't take her class. She acts like it's a 5 credit hour STEM class when in reality it's a meaningless GE. Quizzes are long, hard and time 12 minutes. The essays are ridiculously long and she accused me of using AI when I told her I don't use it. She gave me a bad grade on my final over small things probably because she didn't like me anymore.
If you need to take this class, consider taking it online. This professor is a harsh grader, and their midterm is very difficult.

At first, she was okay but during midterms she was horrible. We had to email her to get approval to do an alternative midterm, but she never emailed a single person back that they got approved. For the history lab, I emailed her multiple questions and she never emailed me back for anything and still gave me an F on that assignment.

> Awesome professor who tied in the readings really well with the lectures, which were concise and extremely informative.
> Definitely should read because midterms and quizzes reference readings.

Lectures are pretty boring, unless you are actually interested in the material. You're graded by weekly quizzes and then a paper for the midterm/final. Although attendance isn't mandatory, the slides she posts sometimes are literally just pictures, so show up to class to get the full context. Also she takes forever to read her messages, so goodluck

She's a very nice lady, asking how everyone's days are to start the class and she tries to liven up the room during lecture even though we are barely awake at 8 am. Midterm was pretty easy but study. There are weekly quizzes so you sort of have to pay attention during lecture because the questions and answers are specific. Overall an easy class.

This is a professor who hopes to teach students by letting them reflect and apply the material rather than restating it, which is a great thing for a professor, but the exams were more difficult than I had anticipated. On the other hand, she is very nice and I learned a lot from her lectures.

Dr. Jones clearly shows her passion and knowledge of the history of public health and her lectures can be entertaining. There are weekly lecture quizzes that are simple and reinforce the important points of lecture. You can generally get away with not doing readings as she goes over them in lecture. Overall, solid professor!

Dr. Jones has a very well formatted and organized class. There is a lot of material & weekly, frequent, and sometimes time consuming homework or exams. Make sure you watch lecture videos, they are informative and cover quiz material directly. Major quizzes are hard and specific, and exams are the same way. Assignments are  time consuming teach you.

Dr. Jones online class is a mess. Dates and assignments are frequently wrong/ unpublished. She also does not post what is due for the week's module until Monday, which means that you can never plan ahead for this class (due dates are on the Sunday of that week). Takes forever to grade and provides very little feedback.

Dr. Rosile was an amazing professor. Even though attendance was mandatory he made you want to come to class because he was really engaging with the students and made everything we were learning applicable to our everyday lives.

Nice guy and an understanding professor but his lecture style is so boring. He often drones on instead of teaching material in a meaningful way. The class is set up in an unnecessarily complicated way and there's a lot of work/ assignments. Probably don't take this class as a GE.

Professor Paul Rosile was an amazing professor. He cared a lot for his students. If you explain your situation he is very understanding professor, matter of fact he will help you out if you need additional help. Yes this class  has a lot of work some are hard and some are easy but if you don't understand the assignment he will help you.

Dr. Rosile clearly cares about his students and the course material, but assignments are extremely repetitive and do not facilitate learning. Directions are always very long, complicated, and confusing. The course is focused on evaluating research rather than learning more directly about climate change's impact on human health.
I love Dr. Rosile, but do not take PUBHEHS4325, as the course is more about random scientific articles and research than it is about climate change and human health.

Honestly do not take a class with this professor. There is a lot of homework and he does not know how to teach the material. You will have to learn everything outside of the designated lecture period because he drones on about the same thing for weeks. The flipped classroom style is a mess and he grades as if he is teaching us the material.

Easy except for the final group project. It was ok but not the best. Classes were 80% lecture and 20% prof trying to get people to participate. He is very nice and very knowledgeable. Flipped classroom style didn't really work because he would just go over it all again during class. Got over 100% in the class because he offers extra credit

Dr. Rosile is very passionate about what he teaches and some of the material is very interesting, but the lectures are so painful to get through. He's trying a flipped classroom style but doesn't have enough information to fill out the time slot, so he just drones on for most of the time. Overall, he's a very nice person and the class is easy.
Very kind professor that is very passionate about his work. Not only that, but he is very communicative and is always accepting of feedback.

This class takes effort. Attendance is important and its a lot of work. But, Dr. Rosile puts in the effort to make the class interesting. He is passionate about the subject and cares that his students are experiencing this passion too. He encouraged my interests and helped me explore EHS careers. put in the effort and you'll be fine

After experiencing both Covid and depression and receiving a doctors note for both of these issues, Dr.Rosile would not unlock the current modules so that I could catch up and stay current in the course. Instead he forced me to continue doing them in order, even though each module is unrelated to the others. Doesn't seem to care about the students.

This was a course more about finding scientific resources and interpreting at scientific information than it was about climate change and human health (the title of the course). It felt fairly disorganized, with difficult to interpret instructions for homework and a heavy load of busy work.

This class is easy and there are no exams or quizzes. You basically work on a semester long project with your group every week. There are homework assignments and journals. The assignments are very easy they both took me no longer than an hour at best. Everyone ends up with an A. I ended with a 99% A.

This class at its roots is easy. There are no exams and your grade is based mainly around a semester-long group video project. The topics are interesting and Dr. Rosile is very passionate about his field. However, the class is not organized well and is heavy in "busy work".

Dr. Rosile is scrambled most of the time and the entire class is busy work and one meaningless group project. It is extremely easy, just follow the rubric and turn in assignments. Each week there is a reflection, homework, learning activity, and group project stuff due. It's not a lot I swear, it's super easy no exams. Turn stuff in and participate

Dr. B is an awesome professor! 4370 was one of the first health science classes I've actually learned a lot in and I got a lot out of the class. Her exams are very fair, you do need to study a little and take notes in class but nothing unreasonable. Dr. B is very personable and kind and truly wants all of her students to succeed.

Listen take this class if you want to actually learn something. Its not hard if you put in the work or pay attention. I read these reviews before and was scared thinking she would be tough. This is the first professor who genuinely cares that we understand what she's teaching. Worst part about this class was coordinating the group work.

Extremely disorganized and showed up late to class most days including exam days which left us with less time to take the exams which were a lot of extended response. She was unprofessional and kept adding assignments at the very end of the semester. A lot of group work with a lack of time to actually discuss or even meet our group members.

I had high expectations for Dr B, but I was honestly disappointed by her lack of professionalism and felt as though she lacked mutual respect. She would constantly show up to class late and would sometimes even eat as she lectured which was gross. I really felt like this class was at the bottom of her priorities and it took forever to get grades

My favorite professor hands down in all my four years at OSU! Dr. B is a great professor that cares about her students, and allows her students to have their own opinion! You still have to try hard in her class but she gives you the recognition for your hard work! If you had to take one piece of advice from me, GO TO HER TEST REVIEW SESSIONS!

Dr. B is an amazing professor, the bad reviews on here are from her online course. Her in-person lectures are amazing and she makes the tests based on the things you talk about in class, she doesn't reuse old tests. If you go to class and pay attention you will pass if you study the study guide. No need to read the textbook. Group work sucks tho.

Dr. B is probably the best professor the Health Sciences major has to offer. Her class is very straightforward in terms of expectations for assignments/projects and test content. Her exams are very fair. You will succeed if you come to class and listen - the majority of things covered on her tests are very obviously highlighted in lectures.
She was very nice but her lectures were very dry. I could tell she cared about her students and I liked that she was very relatable but her teaching style was not my favorite.

Dr. B is an amazing teacher and such a kind person. If you show up to lecture and pay attention during class you will be just fine. Dr. B is the most understanding and supportive teacher I have had at Ohio State

Professor B is disorganized. Forgets to open modules, forgets to set due dates, gives feedback to a paper you submitted over 2 months later and BARELY ANY direction or instruction of what the assignment or papers are supposed to be. Group work was awful. I was in a group were only 2/5 people actually did work - she didn't care and we barely got anA

This class was absolutely horrible. Professor B is very disorganized and not great at teaching. I didn't take anything away from that class material wise. We were forced to complete everything as a group project in groups of 5-6 and she didn't care if only 3 people did all the work. It was so much work for 3 credits. DEFINITELY NOT WORTH IT.
She is so wonderful! I have gotten on her virtual office hours before and we talked about life for almost an hour. She cares so much about her students and is so understanding.

Not accessible outside of class. Very scatterbrained. Showed up unprepared most days to lecture. Exams had info that we did not learn. Just be patient with her. She tries to relate to her students, its just frustrating her all over the place-ness!

One of the best lecturers in the Health Sciences department. Policy was not an easy class but she was always very knowledgable about all of the topics and created a great environment for asking questions. There were a lot of exams but the review sessions helped immensely. VERY slow grader though and policy briefs were a complete disaster.

Dr B was a caring teacher. However, her online courses were very unorganized and hard to follow. She also had us do a lot of group projects and outside homework that didnt relate to what we were learning in lecture.

If you are a Health Sciences student, you will eventually have Dr. B at some point. I cannot convey how good of a thing that this is. Dr. B has restored my faith in professors with her humor, positive attitude, and care about students. If you give effort and are actively listening during class you will succeed. She rocks!

Dr. B is one of the best professors I've had at OSU. She is young so she relates to you on a friendly level and is very flexible with adjusting due dates during assignment-heavy weeks. She makes lectures interesting and does a great job at highlighting information you will be tested on.

Dr. B is the best! Her lecture style is so relaxed and she condenses the material in a easy to understand way. She's little all over the place sometimes but not in a "you forgot to go over what we SHOULD know" way but more of a "giving a very specific example to help you understand the information better" way. Great prof!

Dr. Bs the best! I also took case studies with her (in class!) and that was great. She makes class really relaxed and discussion based. She really cares about her students and enjoys laughing/making class interesting. I took 3 classes with her and wish I couldve taken more. Shes a fairly new prof so shes kinda a friend and mentor to a lot of us

She was really passionate about the material and you could tell. Some of the assignments were harshly graded and the exams were pretty tough. I liked her as a professor but the grades given back to me did not reflect the work I put in.

Dr. Paul is a very good professor and her class is pretty easy and not much work! She does her best to make a boring topic fun. Final project is a bit overwhelming but she is always willing to look it over early on and she is good about responding to questions in her email.

Drones on and on during lectures, I could not go 5 minutes without getting distracted by something like the color of the ceiling or how many blackboards there were (4). Reads off the slides for the entire time I don't think she knows how to use Canvas.

This class is absolutely awful. I was very excited to learn this stuff and in theory this class should be interesting  but it's not. I think she's obsessed with assigning things to students even if there is no merit to it. Truly not sure how she managed to make such a great topic so awful and daunting.

Dr. Paul is not a good professor. The content is interesting but not enjoyable since you have to remember every single detail or you will fail. She also is a horrible responder to emails. The class does not let you show how much you know or have learned, it feels as though she is constantly trying to find ways to dock your grade.

Before this semester I looked Dr. Paul up and became very scared due to the reviews. However she made many adjustments to the course this semester to improve the class. The final project seems daunting and time consuming, however I feel like it was very valuable to my future career in public health. Overall she is a great professor.

Tis class had so many components to it. Dr. Paul made assignments harder than they needed to be and she graded just as harder or even harder. We had a huge group project and our honestly did really well but she graded us harshly and a lot of people's grades drop at the end. The public health classes are easy but this one was hard for no reason.

Test questions were based off of arbitrary facts briefly mentioned within lectures. This class was made so much harder than it needed to be. Major grade-changing projects were required to be completed in groups (even with the pandemic). Not accommodating.

Do not take this class with Dr. Paul. The material of the class is not difficult, however, she makes quizzes/exams much more difficult than they need to be. Her lectures are dry and you must be paying attention 100% of the time to get the needed material for quizzes/exams otherwise you will not find it in the textbook/anywhere else.

She is the worst professor I have ever had. She makes the content of this class way harder than it has to be. She gives no slack on grading. Very limited instructions and does not allow room for error even when she is at fault. Grades extremely hard, even discussion posts. Your best effort still will not be enough.

This class was so interesting and fun. Dr. Lynch made sure that all assignments and readings were meaningful, no busy work or unnecessary assignments. Enjoyed the lectures a lot as well, and the guest speakers we had.

The class was not difficult, but boring. She does grade hard on one of the assignments, this will determine your grade. Literally reads off lecture slides to teach. condescending during email communication. Poses vague writing prompts, then grades hard when you misinterpret. I feel I was treated poorly by her. Dr. Klebanoff(coteacher) is better.

Dr. Nemeth is fantastically qualified to teach this course and has an extensive network that makes this class feel so applicable to the real world. The material is very challenging, both academically and emotionally, but she does an incredible job translating it to practice with you. There is a LOT of reading, but most of it is very much needed.

This class is very easy - follow the detailed directions on the homework and you'll do fine, and the tests aren't weighted heavily. I felt like I could have gotten a lot more out of this class, but the material was broad, and the professor was sometimes condescending. Overall, its easy.

She is really nice and is a good lecturer. There are weekly assignments and she gives great directions and sources to help you complete the assignment. Midterm and Final aren't weighted heavily which is nice for people who are good test takers.

Dr. Ricks has so much expertise to share and does so very well. She is one of the few professors I've found who gives you concise reading assignments that never feel like busy work. The semester long project was challenging, but extremely manageable and really teaches you a lot. She's an excellent professor!
Good luck

This professor was completely unwilling to hear out my concerns about this class. She said nothing could be done to help my success in the class. Does not care about her students and is very performative with little substance.

Professor Chettri is a great professor, There was a ton of work, but imo it offset other assignments. Weekly quizzes open-note, one 3ish page creative paper, one research paper, discussion boards, and some small web-interactive assignments. I read the other review on her and yes it is a lot of work but I did it taking more than a full course load.

This professor was unorganized and unresponsive. She assigned more material than most 5 hour graduate classes (this is a 3 hour undergrad), but made many contradictory statements between assignment descriptions and rubrics and took over a WEEK to respond to questions. Clearly used recycled material that she was completely unfamiliar with.The worst.

Easy grader and clearest grading criteria of all time. Lecture heavy but with application practice every day. Lots of group work but not bad. Definitely would take her class again. She was extremely helpful when I had a conflict with the final exam. I took it for my major, but I know it counts for a GE and I would definitely recommend it.
Exams are slightly hard but not ridiculous. She's a decent professor and topics are actually interesting.

The class was a positive experience, but could get dry sometimes. She read pretty much directly off the slides, but attendance was a must because we would have surprise in-class assignments which counted as an attendance grade. Grading criteria for her assignments could have been a bit clearer, but she was friendly and responsive to emails.

Kaleb was a great professor. Do not start assignments last minute. 
The class in my opinion was easy and interesting.
He offers extra credit here and there. 
You have one week to complete assignments, and he was always there to answer questions over email. 
He gave great feedback. No tests. Small quizzes each week. One large project, and a paper.
Terrible.

DO NOT take this class unless you are ready to put more work into this online class than your major courses, as most people were taking this class for a GE Credit. Halfway through the semester, the head of the course had to cut down the work because it was too much. She told me that they had already cut down the course before that... don't take:)

Dr. Odei is an *excellent* professor that truly cares about his students and his profession. He consistently makes himself available, whether it be via email or via office hours. I had quite a few issues, personal and academic and he helped me through him. My advice is to start early, ask questions, and reach out to him!

A quiz per week on a video lecture online, then an activity and lab per week. Super organized. Doesn't really teach in person but somehow I learned a lot. Group project and individual paper are big parts of grade. Exams are not bad if you look at the study guides. I had 0 experience coding before this class and now I feel like I have a strong base

Probably the worst professor I've had at OSU. He does not seem to care about his students. Grading unclear at times. Does not respond to emails within an expected timeframe. Belittles in office hours. The actual course material was not too bad, but he makes it hard somehow. Take someone else if you can, your grade and mental health will be better.

Amazing professor!!! I absolutely loved taking his course. For me, it was challenging, but he is there encouraging you to find the answer for yourself. It also helps that he has a great sense of humor and I really appreciate him and what he has taught me. He is a professor who cares for his students and is very welcoming.

I am currently taking Dr. Odei for 2210 (online and asynch). I am amazed at what a caring professor he is, he is super quick at replying to emails and addressing concerns with the group project. He is extremely nice during office hours and his course is a lot of work but I LOVE him- not enough good things to say about him.

Professor Odei is a really cool dude if you talk to him outside of class, the assignments aren't hard once you realize they all build on each other and are repetitive. Midterms and finals are open book.

Grading criteria unclear at times. Somewhat belittling in office hours; prepare to get talked over. Lecture due every Monday, usually 1-2 group project activities a week, and a lab due every Thursday. He's knowledgable though and will try to help you understand the concepts. The 2 exams aren't that difficult, open notes and online.

I literally switched my major to public health after this class. I would say that the time in class is not productive, and most of the homework out of class takes some time to do (1 page writing and 1 easy quiz a week for the most part), but the content is very interesting. We read novels relating to public health. Loved this class and professor
Not difficult but not particularly interesting. Seems generally nice but came off as very condescending in emails and one-ones.
A nice enough professor, but not very engaging and often comes across as condescending

Class consisted of asynchronously watching a lecture and videos each week and then 1 page reflections about what you watch. In person meetings were a lot of cool guest lecturers and discussions about topics. Not very much work, no tests. 1 group research paper and 1 "final" project that is really easy

I took case studies in epidemiology my freshman year and loved having Dr. Ferketich. Even though the class was 3 hours long and in the evenings, I always looked forward to it. She gave group projects, but they were interesting and actually helped us learn the material. She also brought snacks every week.

I heard amazing things about this class, but with the way it is set up I was super disappointed. A different TA teaches each module and each quiz is written completely differently making them hard to study for. Her rubrics and syllabus are extremely vague on projects as well, and asking for clarity from her or the TAs was not helpful at all.

The best class I've taken at Ohio State so far. Small class, about 15 people and totally focused on case studies. For older students, great way to apply what you've learned in other classes. For freshmen, great opportunity to learn from her and students that have been in the program

Brent definitely cares about his students. Any time I have attended office hours, he has gone above and beyond to explain the material in a way I understand, never made me feel dumb about asking a basic question, and took the time to really make sure that all my concerns with the assignment and class were addressed. Easily one of the best TAs here.

He does not really seem likes he cares about teaching the material. He is only there for the paycheck. He just reads through the slides and that is it. Would be better if he showed more passion for the material. 

He also kept the course online even after saying he would move it in person.

Brent was my TA for this course and was by far (BY FAR) the greatest TA I have had in my four years of college. Any time I had a question or wanted to review before exams, he was happy to schedule a meeting and answer anything with great explanations. If you put in a good amount of effort on the homework, an A is easily achievable. Brent is 10/10!

Dr. Reiter is one of the BEST professors and faculty at OSU! He is very professional, caring, and willing to help students pass his course(s). His teaching style and compassion for students makes attending OSU worthwhile. He certainly had a positive impact on my graduate school experience. I highly recommend him! Dr. Reiter rocks!

Dr. Reiter has a ton of cool experience he brings to the course. I think for some the material could be dry, but he made it so interesting. I found his lectures so useful, interesting, clear, and concises that I sent them to my former health research coworkers. This was the most useful course of my MPH so far, & his expertise is critical to that.

Dr. Reiter was great. This class was my second time having him and while he is a little monotoned, his lectures show that he a professional in his field. I learned a lot from him, and I will say that is very receptive to any and all feedback whether it be content from lectures or how the class is structured!
Good guy, wants you to learn in fun ways. Doesnt just push tests or massive papers.

this class was super interesting and I really enjoyed it! Easy A if you do the work!!! I would say I spent an average of 30 min per week on this class and got an A. The actual class sessions are super easy and lowkey. Paul is very kind and understanding and knowledgeable in his field. Guest lectures are usually very good as well. Class can be long

Dr. Reiter makes this class so much fun! If you don't have an interest in PubH, don't take it. There's a paper every week, 3 short answer questions every other week, and one 3-hour presentation (not as bad as it sounds). If you do the work and put in effort, you'll get the A. But it's a lot of work

My favorite professor to learn from in 6 years at OSU. The lectures are so clear, so well thought out. The organization of the courses is fantastic. It does involve a good amount of work, but I never felt it was a waste of time or busy work. She makes me regret not choosing epidemiology or biostats as my focus for grad school.

My favorite professor to learn from in 6 years at Ohio State (undergrad + grad school). Her lectures are so clear, her organization is unbeatable, and I genuinely came away from this class feeling confident in everything she taught me. Makes me regret not doing epidemiology. There is a lot of work with the course, but nothing you don't learn from.

My experience with Dr.Andridge was very positive. I really appreciate how she teaches (you do a weekly lab and quizzes and assignments ) so you get plenty of practice before exams. She will also take time to explain concepts and make sure that you understand it by the end of her explanation. I would highly recommend taking any course with her.

Dr. Andridge is a very difficult professor to work with and does not respect her students. When difficult situations arise in the classroom she's been shown to handle them extremely unfairly and without respect and careful consideration. If you're looking for fair treatment and respect from your professor I would not recommend Dr. Andridge.
She is a great professor; gives extremely good feedback. If you work for it, you can easily get an A

I loved this class with Gia. They are so enthusiastic and have so much experience to share. There is a good amount of reading that I struggled to keep up with but it rarely impacted my ability to participate. Participating in their class is so thought-provoking and you can really get a lot out of it. Gia will challenge you, and it rocks!

Gia is one of those professors I will never forget. Not only are they well educated in the topic they are lecturing on, but it is very apparent that they are passionate about it as well. Their lectures are very fast paced, but that just further illustrates that they love what they do. I would take them again in a heart beat!
She gives every opportunity to do well in this class and to communicate with her as an instructor. Highly recommend!

Dr. Gallo is not patient or inviting when it comes to students questions. She responds in quite a defensive and irritated manner. She is also very contradictory. She says she is not trying to trick you and writes her tests/assignments in a very technical way.

She is a tough grader, but she intends well. She wants to make sure youre prepared and that you know your material. The book for the class is arduous, but her lectures really help concepts come to life and the homeworks help make those concepts more concrete. I would highly recommend her!

Class was asynchronous so she offered office hours 4 times a week. Her lecture videos were extremely long and very dry content. There were 2 big assignments that made up a large portion of the final grade: a creative endeavor and a research paper. No exams just weekly quizzes. Overall good GE class!

Lemeshow is a good guy, super smart. Hes not a great teacher. He expects everyone to be a statistician and teaches over our heads often. The class isnt unfair, but he just reads from his notes and spits out statistical jargon. He sometime tells fun stories though that help.
Goes very quickly but explains things well and gives partial credit on tests.
Boss dog was AWESOME. Dr. Lemeshow is a seasoned statistician with amazing stories from his past experiences.
Dr.Lemeshow feels annoyed when asked to clarify. He is a a great scientist but his teaching is not clear. He is very fast and does not explain everything needed.

Very difficult- I flew through 701 but almost didnt pass this course. Notes seem fairly straightforward but tests can seem overwhelming. Be sure to understand the notes instead of just memorizing or you'll be out of luck on the exams. Failed a large portion of the class.

Lemeshow is more brilliant than I will ever be. I sucked in the class. However, he is not as good an instructor as  Drs. Burr and Shen. Both of them left OSU, under Lemeshow as the Dean. Didn't suck up to him enough, perhaps? He should be in a purely research role; not an administrator, not a teaching faculty member.
Dr. Miller is the best. Very intelligent, yet a great teacher as well. Learned a lot from him

Bill is both a great guy and a great professor. He is a certified genius in his field but doesn't come off as a know it all. He cares a lot about both the course content and his students and wants you to do well while actually learning. The outbreak investigation is a good amount of work, but that hard and actually pretty fun overall.

There were only 3 graded assignments, but no tests. She did a great job recruiting experts to talk about epidemiology, climate, and other subjects as well as lecturing on diverse topics herself. She trusts the expertise of her students and discussions often involved the undergrad backgrounds of classmates. The only drawback is disorganization

I would not recommend this class to ANYONE. This prof does not interact with the class at all and relies heavily on her TA's which is fine, but she is the one writing the exams. So, most of the material on the exams was not covered by the TA making this class unnecessarily difficult. Avoid this professor if possible!

Avoid this professor if you can. She was not interested in helping or interacting with the class at all. Calculations appeared on the exam that were never covered during classes or in the textbook. Good luck if you have to suffer through this class for your degree.

She re-used other instructors material without first familiarizing herself with material and when other instructor material wasn't available she used YouTube videos. I was pretty underwhelmed especially considering this should have been graduate level. Because of her reliance on others the homework wasn't always based on lecture materials.
